title: Functions & Scope
description: Test your understanding of JavaScript functions and variable scope.

questions.question: What is the difference between function declarations and function expressions?

options.text: Function declarations are hoisted, function expressions are not

questions.explanation: Function declarations are hoisted to the top of their scope, meaning they can be called before they are defined. Function expressions are not hoisted.

questions.question: What will arrow functions inherit from their surrounding code?
questions.explanation: Arrow functions do not have their own 'this' binding. They inherit 'this' from the enclosing lexical scope. They also don't have an 'arguments' object.

questions.question: What is a closure in JavaScript?

options.text: A way to close a function
A function that has access to variables from an outer function's scope

questions.explanation: A closure is a function that retains access to variables from its outer (enclosing) function's scope, even after the outer function has finished executing.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'return' statement?

options.text: To exit the function and optionally return a value

questions.explanation: The 'return' statement ends function execution and specifies a value to be returned to the function caller. Without it, functions return 'undefined'.
